supporting_text: The NAP emphasizes a collaborative approach to be undertaken in the fight against AMR and endorses a concerted 'One Health' approach — which linked various sectors and actors in defense of human, animal and environmental health.
The NAP includes specific actions in the human health sector, including improving surveillance in human health sectors and controlling the consumption of antimicrobials.
The NAP includes actions aimed at improving surveillance in animal health sectors and controlling antimicrobial consumption in veterinary practices.
The NAP outlines actions to undertake preventive measures from environmental contamination and stop the spread of infection.
The NAP includes actions related to the agricultural sector, particularly in controlling antimicrobial use in livestock and improving practices among herders.
The NAP assigns a multi-sectoral national committee to monitor, discuss implementation results every half year and inform government ministries.
The NAP includes specific targets such as reducing the Daily Defined Dose (DID) of antimicrobials by 10% over the implementation period.
The NAP includes targets for estimating and reporting on antimicrobial consumption and resistance rates.
The required budget for the implementation of the NAP was estimated to be 13,914,468,019.12 MNT, with allocations specified for various strategic areas.
The NAP includes a budget estimation exercise that outlines the required budget for various activities over the implementation period.
The NAP assigns the establishment of a multi-sectoral national committee to ensure implementation and monitoring of the NAP.
The NAP includes actions to revise and update regulations related to antimicrobial use and to conduct assessments on the legal framework in the agriculture sector.
The NAP includes plans to incorporate AMR training modules in high school curricula and postgraduate training programs for veterinary professionals.
The NAP outlines plans to disseminate information through media regarding AMR and to organize public awareness campaigns.
The NAP mentions joining international networks and movements combatting AMR to learn and exchange information.
The NAP includes actions to improve detection and surveillance of antimicrobial resistance and strengthen capacity to collate, analyze, and inform data on AMR.
The NAP includes actions to strengthen the capacity of laboratories to detect and report AMR.
The NAP includes actions to improve infection prevention and control and undertake preventive measures from environmental contamination.
The NAP includes actions to translate and discuss international standards related to AMR.
The NAP includes actions to develop regulations on prescription in the veterinary sector and to maintain essential medicine lists.
The NAP includes actions to require good manufacturing practices for local antimicrobial manufacturing and to implement antimicrobial stewardship programs.
The NAP emphasizes the need for international collaboration and participation in research initiatives related to AMR.
